awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Surface Interactions in Dissimilar Material Joining
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award supports fundamental research on two thermo-mechanical joining methods for dissimilar metals, namely magnetic pulse welding and friction stir blind riveting. Joining methods for dissimilar metals are in increasing demand as manufacturers are seeking creative new structures or components with tailored properties for lightweight vehicles, energy production, consumer devices, or next-generation medical and electrical products. However, dissimilar metals cannot be joined using traditional fusion-based welding methods. This research will provide much needed understanding to enable wide applications of these two joining processes for dissimilar metals. Additionally, this award supports activities to engage students in research; raise students' interest in science, technology, and engineering; and promote advanced manufacturing to a broader population. 

The research objectives are: (1) to correlate local mechanical properties (modulus, hardness, and toughness) across the joining interface with joint performance (tensile strength and failure modes); (2) to test the hypothesis that tensile strength of both magnetic pulse welding and friction stir blind riveting joints increases as the thickness of intermetallic compound or amorphous layer increases up to a few tens of micrometers, and then decreases as the thickness increases further; and (3) to establish the relationships between process parameters, microstructure, and joint performance properties. To achieve the first objective, joining samples will be prepared using the two joining processes under various process conditions. Local mechanical properties will be quantified through micro-cantilever, micro-hardness, and in situ scanning electron microscope testing. Joint performance will be measured through macro quasi-static tensile tests. To achieve the second objective, intermetallic compound or amorphous layers of different thickness values will be produced by adjusting process parameters, and the thickness will be measured by analyzing scanning electron microscope or transmission electron microscope images of the interfaces. A relationship between the layer thickness and tensile strength will be established. To achieve the third objective, a set of governing equations from kinetic modeling of diffusion or intermetallic compound growth will be coupled with finite element simulation to predict the local phase and microconstituent volume fractions, which together with the contact conditions under different process parameters will be used to predict the joint performance.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project achieved a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism behind bonding formation between dissimilar metals, as well as the response of welds to external mechanical loading and corrosive environments with four major accomplishments.

Firstly, this research identified the bonding mechanisms associated with various solid-state thermo-mechanical welding techniques (such as magnetic pulsed welding, vaporizing foil actuator welding, magnetic pulse welding, friction stir welding, and ultrasonic welding), the fusion welding method (e.g., resistance spot welding), and laser-based additive manufacturing processes (e.g., direct energy deposition. This investigation revealed that the phases formed at the bonding interface are primarily determined by local temperature history, pressure, and element distributions. The energy input, in turn, determines whether local melting occurs or not.

Secondly, this research demonstrated that in addition to galvanic corrosion, the gap geometry at the bonding interface plays a critical role in the generation of corrosion products and the corrosion sequence in dissimilar material joints. This is because of the gap geometry that influences the local pH value, which in turn affects the occurrence of crevice corrosion. This investigation also revealed that crevice corrosion can cause corrosion of aluminum workpieces even when coupled with more active materials such as magnesium.

Thirdly, this research characterized the mechanical behaviors of dissimilar material joints at different scales, including quasi-static tensile, dynamic fatigue, and micro compression testing, to gain insights into their failure modes and initiation mechanisms.  

Fourthly, this project unveiled the process-structure-property relations associated with different welding techniques (e.g., friction stir blind riveting, resistance spot welding) and additive manufacturing processes (e.g., direct energy deposition) by combining data fusion and multiscale materials and mechanical characterization techniques. This investigation into these relationships provided valuable insights into the underlying failure modes and how process conditions influence them. Through this analysis, specific defects that led to failure were identified and a thorough explanation of the underlying failure mechanisms was concluded.

This research holds potential for benefiting society, particularly in the areas of dissimilar materials welding design, corrosion protection for dissimilar material joints, and experimental mechanics. The project has supported the education and training of four Ph.D. and three undergraduate students, providing them with valuable hands-on research experience. The research findings have been integrated into both undergraduate courses (e.g., Manufacturing Processes), and a new graduate course developed by the PI (Weld Design and Performance). Furthermore, the results have been disseminated through various peer-reviewed journals and conferences, contributing to the advancement of this field.

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Jingjing Li
